1. location of software installation should not matter (select PATH if given the option)
2. other languages are permissable ([Python](https://www.python.org/downloads/) & [Julia](https://julialang.org/install/) currently popular)
3. other IDEs are permissable ([VS Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/download), [Positron](https://positron.posit.co/), and [JupyterLab](https://jupyter.org/install) currently popular)

:::

## 2 Types of Report Content

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment .semi-fade-out fragment-index=1}
### Narrative:

[**plain--text**]{.underline} = written in prose (same as any word processor) with formatting indicated by [markdown](https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/markdown-basics.html)^[or (possibly) [$\LaTeX$](https://www.latex-project.org/) if generating a {{< iconify vscode-icons:file-type-pdf2 >}}]:

```
# 1^st^ level heading 

## 2^nd^ level Heading

this is **bold**
this is *italic*

```

:::

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment .fade-in fragment-index=1}
### Computational:{#chunks}

occurs in [**chunks**]{.underline} -- isolated bits of code indicated with either one ([inline](https://quarto.org/docs/computations/inline-code.html)) or three ([code block](https://quarto.org/docs/output-formats/html-code.html)) "ticks":

```{r}                   
#| echo: fenced

library(ggplot2)         #<1>

# Basic scatter plot    #<2>  
ggplot(mtcars, aes(
  x=wt, y=mpg)) + 
  geom_point()
```
1. any {{< iconify devicon:r >}} command you would normally specify within scripts or the console is valid within code chunks (including the loading of packages)
2. comments{{< iconify ant-design:comment-outlined >}} also operational within code chunks 
:::

:::

[BFI dataset](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/psych/versions/2.2.3/topics/bfi) (from `psych` package):

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| eval: true

psych::bfi.dictionary[,c(2,4,6)]
      
```

n = `r nrow(psych::bfi)` [({{< iconify mdi:arrow-left-bold >}} pssstt {{< iconify devicon:r >}} reported this number via [`inline code`](#chunks))]{.smaller}

## Empty Report Shell {#template}

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="45%" .smaller}

1. Create a boilerplate Quarto html document:  
    + `File`{{< iconify maki:arrow >}}`New File`[{{< iconify maki:arrow >}}`Quarto Document`]{.fragment fragment-index=1}[{{< iconify maki:arrow >}}`HTML`{{< iconify maki:arrow >}}`Create`]{.fragment fragment-index=2}  

[2. Verify everything "works" -- render/save within project folder]{.fragment fragment-index=3}  
[3. Use clipboard ({{< iconify streamline:empty-clipboard >}}) to replace content & re--render]{.fragment fragment-index=5}

:::

::: {.column width="55%" .fragment fragment-index=5}

```{r}
#| echo: true
---
title: "SCSU 2025 Psychometrics Report"
author: "I.M. Ah--sum"
title-block-banner: "#4caad8"       #<1>
date: today                         #<2>
format: 
  html:
    theme:
      light: default                #<3>
      dark: darkly                  #<3>
toc: true
toc-location: left
execute:
  echo: false                       #<4>
  warning: false
  message: false                    #<4>
#bibliography: bib.bib
#csl: apa7.csl
---

::: {style="overflow: auto;"}

This report summarizes responses from... 

>Note: any caveats here

:::

# Method

## Participants {#sec-people}

## Materials

# Results

# Conclusions & Summary

## Future considerations

## Limitations

# References
```
1. Choose [any color](https://htmlcolorcodes.com/color-picker/) you like {{< iconify emojione:rainbow >}}
2. Either enter static date or allow {{< iconify devicon:r >}} to auto--update to "whenever you last ran this script" with `date: today`
3. You can either customize however you like or choose from [25 built--in themes](https://quarto.org/docs/output-formats/html-themes.html)
4. Controls chunk reporting activity -- helps keep report "clean" (you can toggle to recieve feedback when you want it)

:::

## Scale Alphas {#alpha}

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="55%"}

1. Understand code chunk (aka script) elements &nbsp;&nbsp;{{< iconify maki:arrow >}} 
2. Copy chunk (hit {{< iconify streamline:empty-clipboard >}}) & paste into "Results" section of template report
3. Ask for Chronbach's $\alpha$ by using inline code:
    + Copy spec on line #12 into Results section (but OUTSIDE of chunk)
    
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}

```{r}
#| echo: fenced

library(psych)

bfi$A1 <- 7-bfi$A1    #<1>

agree <- alpha(bfi[1:5]) #<2>

## Chronbach's stored in
## agree$total

## request by typing:
## `r agree$total$raw_alpha`
```
1. Reflecting `A1` as indicated on [scoring key](#example)
2. Indexing quickest way to subset, but be careful (make sure to check output, even if you don't eventually include in report)

::: {.callout-note}
Your reported $\alpha$ will NOT be rounded -- we can revisit (time permitting) {{< iconify svg-spinners:clock >}}
:::

:::

:::

## Item Response Distributions {#hists}

Not all that interesting but worth looking into, we'll do one histogram as well as a table...

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
Copy ({{< iconify streamline:empty-clipboard >}}) and place underneath previous ($\alpha$) chunk:^[you want to sequence your chunks similar to a normal script -- early stuff higher]

```{r}
#| echo: fenced
#| label: fig-a1
#| fig-cap: "Basic histogram of responses to BFI item A1"

hist(bfi$A1)

```

:::

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}

Ditto here ({{< iconify streamline:empty-clipboard >}} & place under histogram chunk)

```{r}
#| echo: fenced
##| label: tbl-agree
##| tbl-cap: "Agreeableness item distribution properties"

table <- describe(bfi[1:5])

knitr::kable(table[,c(2,3,4,8,9,11,12)])
```

:::

:::

## Cross--referencing... {#crossref}

...can be done to just about any report element...

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment fragment-index=1}

### Sections

Look at line #34 in your .qmd {{< iconify fluent-emoji-flat:eyes >}}  

+ `{#sec-people}` is a **tag** with a [special prefix](https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/cross-references.html#overview)

Call it up via inline code:

```
@sec-people talks about respondents
```

:::

::: {.column width="50%" .fragment fragment-index=2}

### Output

[***Of course***]{.underline} you can also cross--reference data (and summaries such as figures and tables)...

<br>
Try this:

```
@fig-a1 is kinda lame
```

:::

:::

## Bibliography {#bib}

Will auto--update as you add references to your report (keep candidate references in a `.bib` file in your project folder)

:::{.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
```{r}
#| echo: true
@article{young2021analysis,
  title={An analysis of training and vocational rehabilitation services for individuals with intellectual disability},
  author={Young Illies, Marcy and Valentini, Brian J and Ingles, Kristina E and Gilson, Carly B},
  journal={Journal of Vocational Rehabilitation},
  volume={55},
  number={2},
  pages={219--225},
  year={2021},
  publisher={SAGE Publications Sage UK: London, England}
}
```

\*[{{< iconify academicons:google-scholar-square >}}](https://scholar.google.com/) provides this format 

:::

::: {.column width="4%"}
:::

::: {.column width="46%" .smaller}
1. Copy and paste the left--hand citation into a "bib.bib" file
2. Delete the "{{< iconify ph:hash >}}" on line 17 of your .qmd

Call out reference in paper: 

```
see the work of @young2021analysis
```

:::

:::
